Award.AwardTitle: Constraining Englacial Temperatures through Active Seismic Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
1043675/Peters

This award supports a project to collect a vertical seismic profile along the WAIS Divide borehole. A seismic experiment of this type has never before been performed through glacial ice, and the seismic signals recorded at various depths within the ice column will yield detailed in situ information on the effects of temperature, c-axis fabric, and impurities on seismic wave propagation through the ice column when allied to the ongoing and proposed borehole logging and core measurements. The intellectual merit of this work is that it will lay the foundation for inferring the temperature profile of an ice column through active seismic methods. By correlating observed temperatures from the WAIS Divide borehole (a funded and scheduled experiment) to our seismic attenuation measurements, we will develop a proxy for determining temperature from englacial seismic reflections. Better temperature estimates would lead to improved ice sheet modeling and more accurate determinations of future ice sheet mass balance and sea level fluctuations. In addition, better constraints on the seismic properties of the ice column will lead to refined imaging of the subglacial environment and add to our understanding of the basal regime and its role in ice dynamics. These active seismic experiments at the WAIS Divide drilling site will also allow us to determine the remaining thickness of ice to the bed at WAIS Divide with high precision, as well as more accurately constrain the basal conditions and deeper geologic structure existing at WAIS Divide for potential sub-ice drilling. The broader impacts of the proposed work are that it has significant impacts beyond the field of glaciology. A surface-based technique for determining englacial temperatures within the ice sheet will provide better constraints on geothermal flux beneath ice sheets and glaciers. The seismic dataset could provide a valuable arena to test fundamental seismic wave propagation algorithms: in particular, as the specific causes of intrinsic attenuation are modeled phenomenologically, these data will provide an opportunity to conduct process-based studies. The data will also be archived at the IRIS Data Management Center upon completion of the fieldwork.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Constraints on the physical state of the Antarctic Ice Sheet are needed to accurately model and predict its contribution to global sea level. Ice temperature is one such constraint, as warmer ice will deform and flow more readily than cold ice. Therefore, improvements in our ability to infer the temperature profile through the Antarctic Ice Sheet at a given location will advance our understanding of the dynamics of the ice sheet and how it contributes to global sea level now and in the future.

 

The primary goal of this project is to develop a seismic methodology for inferring ice temperature. Here we mapped the ice temperature profile by analyzing the rate at which seismic waves attenuate, or decay, as they travel through the ice; we then compared these seismic measurements to observed ice temperature measurements. We observed that seismic waves attenuate very slowly in cold ice, whereas they attenuate rapidly as the ice approaches the melting point, allowing us to derive a simple relationship between seismic attenuation and temperature through a given ice column. Continuing research is focusing on how the physical properties of the ice column (namely its crystalline structure and the presence of any impurities) may influence these observations through co-located seismic and physical observations at the West Antarctic Ice Sheet ice divide coring site. Direct comparisons between our seismic observations and the physical properties of the ice are being made to further refine this seismic attenuation–temperature relationship.

 

This novel approach for inferring ice temperature provides the scientific community with the ability to constrain the temperature structure of glacial ice without spending the time and heavy logistics required to drill a hole through the ice. Thus, this surface-based seismic approach for inferring ice temperature provides a means for more observations of the temperature structure of the Antarctic Ice Sheet to be made, particularly in dynamic regions where ice coring is unfeasible, which will extend our understanding of ice sheet dynamics and lead to improved constraints on the contribution of the ice sheets to global sea level in the future.

 

Graduate students and early career scientists were involved in the fieldwork and data processing for this project, providing them with valuable experience in implementing a field-based approach to address glaciological questions.
